items.title: Intro video for demos
items.description: Explainer of the demo repo we use in the videos.

items.title: What is GitHub Copilot?
items.description: Rob explains on a high level what #GitHub #Copilot is and what you can expect. The different license types are explained and where you can find certain functionality.

items.title: Getting started with GitHub Copilot Free
items.description: To get started with GitHub Copilot Free you can go to https://gh.io/copilot and open the VS Code link from there. This will trigger your VS Code to install the Copilot extensions and ask you to get started with Copilot for free. This includes 2000 suggestions and 50 chat completions per month, for free.

items.title: Code completions / suggestions
items.description: Enhance your coding experience with AI-powered code completions while you are typing. Also called 'suggestions'. These are the most common way of using Copilot as they show up as a suggestion while you are typing in your editor.

items.title: Chat in IDE
items.description: Communicate with Copilot directly within your IDE for instant assistance. You can have multi turn conversations with Copilot on things in your code, or ask it questions on things surrounding your code, like 'how do I do this in Python', or 'how do I run the unit tests from my terminal'.

items.title: Chat on mobile
items.description: Get coding assistance on-the-go with Copilot's mobile chat feature. This lets you summarize issues/pull requests/discussions, or ask broader questions about a repository for example.

items.title: CLI assistance
items.description: Streamline your command line tasks with Copilot's CLI assistance.

items.title: Code referencing
items.description: Get reference information on code snippets that Copilot generates, if they match public code.

items.title: Unit tests
items.description: Automate your testing process with Copilot's unit test generation.

items.title: Code translation
items.description: Translate code across different languages with ease using Copilot.

items.title: Code documentation
items.description: Generate comprehensive documentation for your codebase with Copilot.

items.title: Code explanation
items.description: Get detailed explanations for complex code snippets with Copilot.

items.title: Code fixing
items.description: Quickly fix coding errors and issues with Copilot's assistance of '/fix'.

items.title: Code debugging
items.description: Simplify the debugging process with Copilot's insightful suggestions. Copilot can use the information of debugger, like the call stack, exceptions, variable values.

items.title: Slash commands
items.description: Enhance your coding workflow with Copilot's slash commands.

items.title: User Instructions
items.description: With user instructions in VS Code you can help guide Copilot in the right direction for your codebase, like being a Python 3 developer and skip older language constructs.

items.title: Integration in Web UI
items.description: Seamlessly integrate Copilot into your web UI for enhanced productivity.

items.title: PR body generation in WebUI
items.description: Automatically generate detailed pull request bodies with Copilot in the webUI.

items.title: Chat with your pull request
items.description: Collaborate more effectively on pull requests with Copilot's chat feature.

items.title: @github chat participant
items.description: Invite @github to your chat for additional assistance with GitHub information in the current repository.

items.title: PR body generation in VS Code
items.description: Create a body for a new pull request using GitHub Copilot, by using the GitHub PR extension! It will analyze the diff between the branches as well as the commit messages, and create a body from it.

items.title: Multi-Models
items.description: Leverage different AI models for various coding scenarios.

items.title: Multi-file Edits
items.description: Copilot can make edits across multiple files in a single suggestion. This greatly improves the way of working by opening both your code as well as your tests for example, and update both at the same time.

items.title: Ice Breakers
items.description: Generate starter templates or boilerplate code to jump-start development.

items.title: Local In-Editor Code Reviews
items.description: Highlight and review suggested code changes directly from within the Visual Studio editor.

items.title: Playwright Test Generation
items.description: Generate Playwright tests for UI testing scenarios directly from existing code.

items.title: Commit Message Suggestions
items.description: Copilot proposes commit messages based on the code changes in the current changeset.

items.title: Commit Message Custom Instructions
items.description: Customize commit messages with tailored instructions for more descriptive and meaningful comments.

items.title: Web search with Bing
items.description: Perform web searches within your coding environment using Copilot and Bing.

items.title: Explain failed action jobs
items.description: Get help from GitHub Copilot to explain why a certain action job failed and help you fixing it.

items.title: Usage metrics
items.description: Track your team's usage of Copilot with detailed metrics and insights.

items.title: Data excluded from training by default
items.description: From the business version and upwards, GitHub Copilot will not use your prompt and nteractions to train Copilot on.

items.title: User management
items.description: This lets you assign licenses per user, for example to every user in a team / organization / or repository.

items.title: Content Exclusions
items.description: With Content Exclusions you can exclude certain parts of your codebase from being sent to Copilot. Think for example of files containing sensitive information, like secrets.

items.title: Chat with knowledge bases
items.description: Access knowledge bases directly through Copilot's chat for quick information retrieval.

items.title: Fine tuned models
items.description: Benefit from models fine-tuned for your specific coding needs with Copilot.

items.title: Set coding guidelines for code review
items.description: Define coding guidelines for Copilot to follow during code reviews.

items.title: Preview for Copilot Workspace
items.description: Technical Preview access to Copilot Workspace is available for Copilot Enterprise users. In this video Rob shows an early version of Workspace and how it lets you work in the context of an issue and the entire repository to get your task executed.

tutorials.title: Troubleshooting GitHub Copilot keyboard shortcuts in Jetbrains IDEs
tutorials.description: Jesse shows how you can troubleshoot keyboard issues in Jetbrains IDE's when your GitHub Copilot tools don't work the way you're expecting

tutorials.title: VS Code supports user input as extra prompt instructions
tutorials.description: Instruct GitHub Copilot with extra user input to get more fitting results. This is especially helpful if you have a specific need for a libary, or SDK version.

tutorials.title: GitHub Copilot video series: Levels of Enlightenment
tutorials.description: Get more proficient using GitHub Copilot with the lessons learned from Rob. In this 10 part series he explains some of the lessons learned while using Copilot over the last year.

tutorials.title: Converting data into a different format
tutorials.description: Learn how to to leverage GitHub Copilot to help with data conversions.

tutorials.title: How to consume an API without an OpenAPI spec
tutorials.description: Having no official specs to build your object model to communicate with an API can be hard. In this post Jesse shows how to make it easier to get the classes you need using GitHub Copilot

tutorials.title: GitHub Copilot Power User example
tutorials.description: In this post Rob takes you by the hand through refactoring a shell script out of a build pipeline into a separate file. He shows how to do this step by stap, including the additional checks and chat questions he is asking to get to the desired result.

tutorials.title: GitHub Copilot Debugging exprience in Visual Studio
tutorials.description: GitHub Copilot is a powerful integrations in Visual Studio that enhances the debugging experience. Read the blogpost and checkout the videos to learn more!

tutorials.title: GitHub Copilot Chat - Power user example
tutorials.description: Learn in an example how much more you can get out of GitHub Copilot Chat from this video from Rob Bos

levels.title: Explain what you want to achieve
levels.description: This video shows how changing the way you write my code helps me get more descriptive with GitHub Copilot so the suggestions you get out of it become a lot better!

levels.title: Know your context
levels.description: This video shows you how to think about the context GitHub Copilot uses and how to use that knowledge to get better results out of it!

levels.title: Copy method calls as comments
levels.description: This video shows how changing the way you go from a method call to the method implementation speeds up creating code!

levels.title: Top-down programming instead of bottom-up
levels.description: This video shows how thinking about the code implementation from top-down instead of bottom up helps me use GitHub Copilot in a better way!

levels.title: Typos in your prompt do not matter
levels.description: This video shows you to stop caring (to much) about typos in your prompt. Took a while to internalize that this is a good way to speed up your prompting!

levels.title: Use the chat
levels.description: This video shows using the Chat functionality to your benefit: instead of relying on suggestions while you are typing most of the time, I have switched to use the Chat for most of the things, as that will get me faster results so I can focus on what I want to do, instead of creating the right syntax.

levels.title: #file is your biggest friend
levels.description: This video shows you how to get the most of of GitHub Copilot by being very descriptive with your prompts and to include specific context by using #file or #selection, instead of relying on the editor to guess what parts of your codebase are important.

levels.title: Accept the truth
levels.description: This video shows about accepting the fact that Copilot is based on Large Language Models, which means it is both non-deterministic as well as not 100% correct. You remain the pilot and are driving the conversation, so you are also the professional guiding the code in a direction. It can take a while to get the code correct

levels.title: Be smart
levels.description: This video explains that you need to be smart when using GitHub Copilot. Think of novel use cases and how to get more done by Copilot instead of writing the code yourself. Use it for exploration and finding new ways of doing things!
